Macbook Setup for Development

28 Sep 2014

Recently I started using Mac OSX for my development needs, got myself a 2014 version Macbook Air last month. It has been a month and it is my new precious. I get around ten hours of charge which is phenomenal.

After a lot of searching and recommendations about which applications to use , this is how I ended up setting up my macbook for web development.

If you have any comments or suggestions, feel free to give me a shout on Twitter

Applications

  • Chrome : Chrome is the best browser, and Chrome developer tools are the best way to debug errors and learn what happens under the hood.
  • Chrome Canary : Chrome Canary allows me to stay ahead with the new features as they get implemeted to chrome.
  • iTerm2 : Better terminal than the one that comes with OSX. I set up a hotkey ⌘ + ⌥ to open the terminal to half of my screen, something like the Guake terminal in linux.
  • Sublime Text: my favourite and the best text editor for any programming language. I use it with 'Consolas' font and Monokai theme.
  • Alfred : One of the must-have applications on mac, open applications blazingly fast by just pressing ⌥ + SPACE and few characters of app name. Once I started using Alfred, I don't find a use for dock.
  • Dropbox: Syncs in the background, easy to store important files and other information.
  • Dash : Documentations for every programing language out there. The best part it is offline and searching with Alfred makes you a lot more productive.
  • Mamp: Apache, PHP and MySQL server. For local Wordpress and PHP development.
  • Evernote : If you're not using this piece of awesome software, you must have one hell of a memory. For mortals, this is so awesome, it helps me track ideas, notes and everthing that I always fail to remember.
  • Anvil : A simple menubar app to manage local sites easily.
  • Skype : For video conferences with people who don't want to use Hangouts.

Command Line

  • Command Line Tools :You first need to install xcode to use command line tools or if you don't do iOS development like me you can just install the tools using $ xcode-select --install on a terminal.
  • brew : apt-get for mac.
  • git : brew install git for version control.
  • zsh : Still haven't strated using it yet but everyone says it is lot better than bash.
